headerText: A flexible design system for resource directories.

caseStudy.content:
I’ve seen how nonprofits and community groups often have to “make do” with inconsistent, improvised directories. The result is confusing layouts, accessibility issues, and a lot of duplicated effort. So, I created OpenResource to see how to solve that problem. So far I have a system that instead of presribing a single look, it establishes core principles that adapt to different organizations, audiences, and styles.

This case tests the system's flexibility by pushing it to an intentionally bold, highly stylistic example.

processIntro: The challenge was to design a system that felt universal and reusable, while still allowing organizations with no design background to make it their own.

gallery.caption:
Initial Sketches

More than anything this system has been a lesson in information architeture. Early on I sketched out many different ways the essential information could be shown to users.

Foundation Sheets

In an attempt to dig my heels into this whole design system thing, I defined a typography scale, spacing system, and defined “grids”.

reflection:
While I'm by no means finished, this project has already taught me the potential of designing a system around principles, rather than fixed aesthetics. This means with one system you can build both simple, neutral directories and highly expressive ones.

As I continue, I will expand the system into layouts and base components to make adoption easier for real nonprofits.
